;欧盟反垄断监管机构针对谷歌利润丰厚的数字广告业务做出了前所未有的决定这家科技巨头出售其部分广告业务以解决竞争问题。

;

;作为欧盟行政部门和最高反垄断执法机构的欧盟委员会表示，其在调查后的初步观点是“只有强制性的谷歌剥离其部分服务”将消除这些担忧。

;

;欧盟委员会周三表示，谷歌“滥用了其在在线广告市场的主导地位”。

;

;欧盟反垄断负责人玛格丽特Vestager 表示，谷歌可能不得不出售其部分广告技术业务，因为行为补救措施不太可能有效阻止反竞争行为。

;

;“我当然知道这是一个强有力的声明，但它反映了市场的性质、它们的运作方式以及为什么行为承诺似乎是不可能的，”她在新闻发布会上说。

;

;谷歌是世界上占主导地位的数字广告平台，拥有 28% 的市场占有率。根据研究公司 Insider Intelligence 的数据，广告收入占全球广告收入的市场份额。

;

;去年，广告技术业务占这家科技巨头总收入的 79%。

;

;其 2022 年的广告收入，包括来自搜索服务、Gmail、Google Play、Google 地图、YouTube 广告、Google Ad Manager、AdMob 和 AdSense 的总计 2245 亿美元。

;

;欧盟高管邀请 Google 现在对这一初步调查结果做出回应，在进行了为期两年的反垄断调查后，最终得出了最终结论。

;

;欧盟 27 国领导了全球打击大型科技公司的运动，但此前它依赖于开出重磅罚款，包括对谷歌的三项价值十亿欧元（美元）的反垄断处罚。

;

;这是欧盟首次命令科技巨头拆分业务关键。

;

;谷歌现在可以辩护在委员会发布最终决定之前提出自己的理由。该公司表示，它不同意反垄断指控，并将做出相应回应。

;

;该委员会的决定源于其于 2021 年 6 月启动的一项正式调查，调查谷歌是否违反了欧盟的竞争规则，偏袒自己的在线产品以牺牲竞争对手出版商、广告商和广告技术服务为代价来展示广告技术服务。

;

;与大型科技公司的斗争：欧盟数十亿的罚款和严厉的法律

;

;YouTube 是该计划的焦点之一委员会的调查，调查谷歌是否利用视频共享网站的主导地位通过对竞争对手施加限制来支持自己的广告购买服务。

;

;谷歌的广告技术业务也正在接受英国反垄断监管机构的调查，在美国面临诉讼。

;

;布鲁塞尔此前在三起反垄断案件中对谷歌处以价值超过 80 亿欧元（86 亿美元）的罚款，涉及其 Android 移动操作系统以及购物和搜索广告服务.

;

;该公司正在对所有三项处罚提出上诉。去年，一家欧盟法院将对 Android 的罚款略微减少至 412.5 万欧元（446 万美元）。欧盟监管机构有权处以高达公司年收入 10% 的罚款。

;

;国泰航空的初级飞行员可以向其预算部门 HK Express 申请高级职位作为香港载旗航空公司留住人才和重建飞行能力的一部分。

;

;国泰航空的副驾驶将被允许在香港快运航空担任副驾驶两年，然后才能返回主要航空公司国泰航空集团周三宣布，在保留更高级别的同时，国泰航空集团宣布。

;

;飞行运营总监克里斯·肯皮斯机长表示，自愿计划旨在满足廉价航空公司对飞行员的短期需求，同时为那些搭乘国泰航空的航班有机会晋升。

;

;随着航班数量的增加，香港国泰航空的新机组人员月薪高达 20,000 港元

;

;香港快运航空正在寻求扩大它服务的目的地数量，并在今年年底前雇用 180 名新飞行员和 300 多名机组人员。

;

;“这一安排将进一步支持我们的发展轨迹，为我们现有的副驾驶提供更多晋升机会成为机长，”航空公司首席执行官 Jeanette Mao Jie-qiong 说。

;

;3 月，该航空公司表示预计到夏季每周运营 500 个航班，覆盖约 22 个目的地。

;

;这家廉价航空公司拥有一支由 27 架飞机组成的机队，这些飞机都是空客生产的窄体客机，这家低成本航空公司在 3 月份接收了 16 架此类飞机中的第一架。

;

;Paul Weatherilt，董事长代表大约一半国泰飞行员的香港机组人员协会表示，他支持新的晋升计划。

;

;但该协会主席指出，国泰仍然缺少机长，国泰航空与国泰航空公司竞争

;

;当被问及新计划是否有助于留住人才时，Weatherilt 说：“离开的不是副驾驶。国泰目前的副驾驶人数与大流行前相同。”

;

;目前尚不清楚香港快运针对初级机师的补偿方案与国泰相比如何，该方案是否足够有吸引力他补充说，或者回到旗舰承运人的返回路径将涉及什么。

;

;邮报看到的一份国泰航空内部备忘录称，与选择香港快运航空飞行两年的人相比，他们可以更快地晋升其他航空公司的培训计划。根据该文件，希望转为廉价航空公司的申请人需要至少 1,000 小时的飞行经验。

;

;然而，一位拒绝透露姓名的国泰初级飞行员表示担心加入该计划的人可能面临在 HK Express 的服务条件下，通过增加短途航班来整体减薪。

;

;国际航空运输协会表示，香港在重建航空枢纽角色方面面临“艰巨”的任务

;

;虽然这两个因素他补充说，这可能会阻止更多注重薪水的飞行员，一些渴望飞行的人可能有兴趣加入该计划。

;

;国泰航空的新晋初级飞行员于 6 月 1 日开始了一项旨在扩大他们的入职培训的试验计划通过在城市机场担任职务，例如在不同岗位接受一线客户培训，积累经验。

;

;国泰集团目前的运营能力约为其 Covid-19 疫情前客运量的 50%，其中公司的目标是到年底达到 70%，到 2024 年底达到 100%。

;

;由于大流行期间旅行需求减少，该公司裁员 5,900 人，关闭了其区域分支机构国泰港龙航空，并启动了政府支持的 390 亿港元（49 亿美元）重组计划。

;

;作为削减成本措施的一部分，国泰集团还为飞行员和机组人员引入了更便宜的雇佣合同。

;

;飞行风险：解开香港国泰航空飞行员的不满

;

;作为提振员工士气措施的一部分，国泰航空周一表示，从 7 月起，机组人员的月收入可能会增长 3% 至 8%，原因是生产力工资，与飞行小时数挂钩。

;

;该航空公司在 1 月份将其基本月薪提高了 3.3%，并增加了飞行员津贴，同时在一个月后推出了新的外港周转津贴。

;

;上个月，三名机组人员因在飞往香港的航班上侮辱一些中国大陆乘客的英语能力而被解雇，国泰航空员工的士气受到打击。

;

;当时，空乘人员工会称士气“极度低落”，需要极度关注。

;

;事件发生之前，国泰航空的飞行员被警告不要在跑道上缓慢滑行，以延长飞行时间并提高工资。当局指责他们助长了机场的拥堵。

; Wed, 14 Jun 2023 20:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong stock exchange operator will help city become ‘world’s leading green finance centre’, says Financial Secretary Paul Chanhttps://www.scmp.com/business/banking-finance/article/3224088/hong-kong-stock-exchange-operator-will-help-city-become-worlds-leading-green-finance-centre-says?utm_source=rss_feed

;交易所运营商香港交易及结算所（HKEX）将继续开发产品和服务财政司司长陈茂波表示，以帮助香港成为“世界领先的绿色科技和绿色金融中心”以及离岸人民币交易中心。

;

;陈茂波在主题演讲中阐述了他的愿景在周三庆祝香港交易所上市 23 周年的仪式上发表讲话。

;

;“随着世界朝着绿色和低碳转型迈进，香港可以做的还有很多Chan 在仪式上说，包括股票经纪人和上市公司代表在内的数百名嘉宾出席了仪式。

;

;“我们的目标是成为全球领先的绿色科技和绿色金融中心.

;

;“我们很高兴地注意到，香港交易所积极为绿色和 ESG [环境、社会和治理] 发展做出贡献，包括推出 [自愿碳交易平台] 以及设置提出加强气候相关披露的建议。”

;

;Chan 提到下周一将推出新的港元和人民币双柜台交易服务，投资者可以在 24 年内以两种货币中的任何一种进行交易公司。他将此描述为人民币国际化的一个重要里程碑，并相信不会有任何障碍。

;

;“我可以向你保证，下周不会有星期一早上的忧郁，”陈说。 “下一步，我们将推动港股通纳入人民币计价证券，让内地投资者可以使用在岸人民币资金买卖港股。”

;

;该仪式是港交所首次推出自 2018 年以来，在 2019 年香港发生社会动荡，然后是 Covid-19 大流行导致庆祝活动中断四年之前，香港交易所通过现场活动庆祝其周年纪念日。

;

;香港交易所是亚洲第三最大的股票市场，将于 6 月 27 日正式纪念上市公司 23 周年。Chan 是周三仪式的主宾，该仪式由证券交易所运营商首席执行官 Nicolas Aguzin 及其董事长 Laura Cha Shih May-lung 主持。

;

;Chan、Aguzin 和 Cha 在 Connect Hall 敲响了仪式锣，该大厅在 2017 年之前用作交易所的交易大厅。

;

;除了绿色金融和人民币产品，Aguzin 表示香港交易所希望吸引更多国际公司上市，更多全球投资者在香港交易。这就是他和查今年多次访问中东的原因。

;

;“中东地区蕴藏着巨大的储蓄。那里的主权财富基金体系有 4 万亿美元，而他们只在香港投资了大约 1% 到 2%，这很小，”Aguzin 说。

;

;“中国占全球 80% GDP，他们应该有 10% 到 20% 的资金通过香港投资于中国公司。我们谈论的是 1 万亿美元，这是一个非常好的机会。

;

;“这就是我们在中东花费如此多时间的原因。该地区也有一些伟大的公司可能希望在世界这一地区寻找潜在的资金来源。”

;

;自 2000 年 3 月通过合并香港交易所成立以来，香港交易所取得了长足的进步。证券交易所、期货交易所和三个结算所。

;

;2000年6月27日在香港上市，每股3.88港元。截至周三收盘，其股价为 313.20 港元。在上市当天以 3,880 港元（500 美元）的价格购买 1,000 股股票现在价值 313,200 港元。

;

;香港交易所经营的交易所上市公司数量也有所增加，从 790 家上市时的2600点，截至周三，总市值增长7倍至32.79万亿港元。

;

;23年来，港交所日均成交量增长9倍，至今年前五个月的交易额为 1,189 亿港元，而截至 5 月，日均衍生品交易量增加了 37 倍，达到 140 万份合约。

;

;多年来，香港交易所的业务多元化。该交易所运营商在 2000 年严重依赖股票交易，但现在其衍生产品也大量交易。它还在 2012 年通过收购伦敦金属交易所向海外扩张。

;

;2000 年，股票市场由企业集团和金融公司主导，这两个行业合计占市场份额的 71%。根据香港交易所的数据，如今它们仅占 44.5%。

;

;2000 年未列入名单的信息技术和医疗保健现在合计占市场的 30%。

;

;香港主板在过去 14 年中七次成为全球首次公开募股的首选场所，这在一定程度上要归功于 2018 年 4 月推出的上市改革。

;

;改革允许拥有多个类别的公司有投票权、没有收入的生物科技公司来港上市，吸引了众多科技公司和医疗保健公司。

;

;确切地说，改革为86家公司打开了在港上市的大门。到今年三月的城市。据财经事务及库务局局长许正宇称，这些公司筹集了超过 5800 亿港元，占同期在香港上市筹集的资金总额的 40% 以上。

;

;其中包括 56 家尚未有收入或尚未盈利的生物科技公司，共筹资 1,160 亿港元，使香港成为此类公司在全球的第二大上市中心，仅次于纳斯达克。

;两栋住宅公寓发生爆炸，造成三人死亡，“多人”受伤警方称，周二晚上在中国北方城市天津。

;

;根据周三在官方微信社交媒体上发布的警方简报，一名涉嫌使用烟花爆竹在两个建筑群中引发爆炸的男子已被拘留媒体报道。

;

;根据天津年鉴，这两起爆炸发生在晚上 8 点后的某个时间，发生在该市的河东区，那里居住着超过 90 万人口，其中包括许多少数民族。

; p>; 两座建筑相距约 1.6 公里（1 英里）。天津位于首都北京东南约 100 公里（70 英里）处。

;

;警方表示，受伤人员已经接受治疗，但没有提供更多细节。

;

;警方的简报中没有说明这名 46 岁马姓嫌疑人​​的可能作案动机尚不清楚，受害者是否认识他。

;

;这起事件发生在中国每年一度的端午节举行前一周左右烟花爆竹经常是庆祝活动的一部分。

;

;近年来，出于安全考虑，中国当局对烟花爆竹进行了严格管制，天津地方当局也对可以使用烟花爆竹的时间和地点进行了限制。

;

;根据上周四会议的官方宣读，中国公安部最近启动了对非法枪支和爆炸物的最新全国“零容忍”打击行动。

;

;150 万美元的中国葬礼烟花引发关于奢侈习俗的争论

;

;在中国版的推特微博上，评论者表示爆炸感觉像是“恐怖袭击”或“对社会的报复”。

;

;虽然故意使用烟花爆竹造成伤害的情况很少见，多年来，中国发生了许多致命的烟花爆竹事故。

;

;5 月，河北省一派出所检查非法烟花爆竹，造成 4 人死亡

;

;两名香港男子因涉嫌非法燃放烟花而被捕

;

;1 月，中部省份山西省一名青少年因点燃烟花而受伤从公共广场的无牌商店购买。法院责令这名青少年的家人和店主向受害者提供经济补偿。

;

;2009 年，中国国家广播公司中央电视台新近开业的总部所在地的一家酒店因一场火灾被烧毁元宵节庆典期间未经授权的烟花汇演。一名消防员遇难，至少 30 人受伤。

;没有证据表明菲律宾政府参与所谓的苏禄苏丹国继承人” 马来西亚总理安瓦尔·易卜拉欣说。

;

;“截至目前，没有证据表明菲律宾政府参与其中。我必须在这里强调这一点，”他在提交紧急动议以允许总理提供有关苏禄案的最新情况后，在下议院或议会下院的特别简报会上说。

;

;“我见过马科斯总统 [Ferdinand Marcos Jnr] 两次。当然，我们被冒犯了，但这不涉及菲律宾政府，”他补充说。

;

;马来西亚将苏禄继承人列为恐怖分子，以驳回 140 亿美元的沙巴索赔

;

;他指出，两国双边关系良好。他补充说，沙巴作为一个主权和独立国家的地位不会受到影响。

;

;安华是在回答国会议员拿督克利尔诺的提问时认为菲律宾政府参与其中在此事和 2013 年拉哈杜塔入侵事件中。

;

; p>;

;他说，这不仅是由马来西亚政府以及沙巴和砂拉越政府决定的，也是由人民决定的。

;

;A student from a prestigious university in China who made false “secret filming” accusations against an innocent man has faced a public backlash over her actions.

;

;Her baseless claims stemmed from an incident on a subway train in Guangzhou, the capital city of Guangdong province in southern China.

;

;When she saw a middle-aged man squatting nearby and using his phone, the woman suspected he might be secretly filming her.

;

;She then demanded the man show her his photo gallery and despite finding nothing, continued to warn him: “Be careful. Don't secretly film others.”

;

;The woman then went on to share a lengthy post on her social media platform which stated: “With such skilful moves and shameless behaviour, it feels like this creepy old man isn't a first-time offender.”

;

;When confronted online about the man's innocence, she insisted: “If he truly didn't take any photos, why did he not speak up for himself?”

;

;The incident gained even more online traction when a man, surnamed Deng, the son of the alleged photo-taker, got involved.

;

;“My father is just a migrant worker. Due to the rain, he had no work at the construction site, so he travelled around Guangzhou. He didn't expect this would happen on his way back on the subway,” Deng told Qilu Evening News.

;

;It has also emerged that the woman is a graduate student from the College of Literature and Journalism at Sichuan University, a prestigious institution in southwestern China.

;

;News of the incident quickly went viral and has dominated mainland social media for several days.

;

;On the popular short-video platform Douyin, the Chinese version of TikTok, a single hashtag related to the incident attracted millions of views.

;

;On the widely used social media platform Weibo, several hashtags emerged amassing more than 2 billion views.

;

;In the face of fierce public scrutiny and potential punishment from the school, four days after the incident, the girl issued an apology.

;

;She posted: “I should not have spread the video on the internet and made inappropriate comments about your personal image.”

;

;The victim's son accepted the apology and said: “She is a university student, while we are migrant workers. She has a higher level of education and if she made a mistake, we should give her a second chance.”

;

;However, online criticism of the woman has continued.

;

;“This is blatant cyberbullying,” said one online observer.

;

;Another commented: “This is clearly an unfair battle. A graduate student majoring in journalism and engaging in an online war with an elderly man who may not even know how to fully operate a smartphone.”

;

;“If students like her end up holding sway over the media discourse in the future, where will we find credible news?” added a third.

;

;Around the same time of the subway incident, another Weibo post uncovering networks of hidden cameras used by criminal gangs and received 45,000 reposts was censored.

;

;An online observer, whose comment attracted 27,000 likes, said: “Even though numerous hidden cameras remain in the dark, it is astonishing how a false accusation can instantly become a hot topic. It seems like the entire internet is eager to 'hunt down' women.”

;Having worked in real estate in eastern China for more than a decade, Lin Ling is planning to leave the industry and start a snack bar instead.

;

;“I've got nothing to do at work. There's simply no buyers,” said the 40-year-old sales manager from Jiaxing, Zhejiang province.

;

;Lin's salary has been cut by a third since the start of the year, with her company struggling to reduce costs and destock amid an ailing property market.

;

;“The good days aren't coming back. I have to try something else now,” she added.

;

;4 takeaways from China's May trade data as exports tumbled

;

;China's slowing economic recovery has added to Lin's decision as disappointing manufacturing activity, exports data and youth unemployment failed to back up better-than-expected growth in the first quarter.

;

;The world's second-largest economy had shaken off Beijing's restrictive coronavirus restrictions at the end of last year, but exports dropped to their second-lowest level since May 2022 last month, while factory activity contracted further to the lowest level since the end of last year.

;

;The slowdown, partially driven by weak overseas demand, has forced a large number of Chinese factories and traders to put investment on hold, and instead focus on reducing operating costs, shutting down production lines and cutting jobs.

;

;“Traditional manufacturers I know saw their orders drop by 40 per cent or more so far, compared to the same period last year, and we feel more pessimistic with our expectations for the coming months,” said Wang Jie, an original design manufacturer focused on the footwear industry in Dongguan, Guangdong province.

;

;“Take my factory for example, there will be no new orders at all starting next week.”

;

;Wang's factory now employs predominantly casual workers, with the number of full-time staff reduced by around two-thirds from last year to less than 20.

;

;Factories are also switching to smaller premises, according to Wang, but such moves are being made at the cost of quality, meaning products will struggle to pass European and American standards.

;

;“The boss already has no other way to solve the cash flow problem,” added Wang after watching a neighbouring firm move into an old tin factory.

;

;High inventories are also causing problems after three years of coronavirus-related curbs and restrictions clogged supply chains, which are affecting investments.

;

;“Companies are changing from going after high quantities to setting their minimum order quantities, which means suppliers or manufacturers will ensure profitability and justify the costs associated with producing or delivering the products,” said Paul Tai, the regional director at Mainetti Retail Solutions Worldwide, which operates production lines in eastern and southern China.

;

;“In that case, companies will focus on upgrading their operations and investing in different capacities, eg software that helps digitalisation.

;

;“[The fashion industry] accepts the fact that the overall global demands will decrease by 20 per cent in the coming three years. Instead of pouring money to expand their facilities, the trend will turn to strong companies acquiring small companies. More precise investment considerations will be made.”

;

;3 takeaways from China's price data as deflation worries rose

;

;The new energy vehicle manufacturing industry is also feeling the strain of a weak domestic market.

;

;“We were producing at full capacity in January. But in the first quarter, the capacity was at an average of less than 60 per cent, and it is expected to rise to only nearly 80 per cent in June,” said an after sales engineer at a Guangxi-based automotive components firm, who asked not to be identified as they are not authorised to speak to the media.

;

;“The main reason is that the domestic auto brands are very competitive, and there is a lot of pressure on material inventory as our clients' sales performance is not as good as they thought.”

;

;Many individuals are also tightening their belts in preparation for a prolonged period of economic weakness, showing growing caution in their personal investments.

;

;Zhu Rui, a Guangzhou-based retired businessman, sold a two-bedroom property in Guangzhou last month for 4.7 million yuan (US$657,000) due to the continually glooming market.

;

;“I am still satisfied with the deal, although it is actually lower than last year's market price of around 5.3 million yuan, I think the price will continue to fall in the future,” said Zhu.

;

;He swapped 3 million yuan into a three-year fixed deposit with an interest rate of 3.25 per cent, while he plans to buy short-term US dollar-denominated financial products with the remaining income from the sale.

;

;“I am also more cautious about China's stock market and other investments in the domestic market. Every day I see more lay-offs and pay cuts occur in growing industries and companies,” Zhu added.

;

;People are also reluctant to make significant expenditures despite a pickup in less expensive items such as dining and travel since China's reopening late last year.

;

;“Fundamentally, the confidence of the Chinese people is low due to the uncertainty about the economic recovery,” said Xu Bin, a professor of economics at China Europe International Business School.

;

;“They had hopes for an economic recovery in the few months after the abandonment of the strict pandemic-control policy in November last year, but gradually they realise that economic recovery is not coming with this policy switch.”

;

;China's economy grew by 3 per cent in 2022, missing the long-abandoned growth target of “around 5.5 per cent” for last year.

;

;It then beat expectations in the first quarter of this year, growing by 4.5 per cent compared to a year earlier, but China's consumer prices only grew mildly in May, while factory-gate deflation deepened, adding to concerns. Export growth also tumbled last month, indicating weak external demand.

;

;“The pandemic was a major reason for the toughness of China's economy, but it has become increasingly clear that there are deeper reasons for the Chinese economy to be weak this year and possibly in the years ahead,” Xu added.

;

;“Until the Chinese people's confidence comes back, it is rather hard to imagine that the Chinese people will suddenly spend on big items (for example houses, cars and luxuries) again.

;

;“The confidence relies on positive expectations for future economic growth, which hinges on the commitment of the Chinese government to pro-growth policies.”

;

;On Tuesday, China's central bank cut a key policy rate in a clear signal of monetary loosening to support the struggling national economy.

;

;But cosmetics producer Kelly Fang does not expect too much for the upcoming June 18 online shopping festival, with the 618 event seen as the second-most important e-commerce in China after Singles' Day in November.

;
